concept.title: Information architect
concept.shortdesc: Information architects are responsible for defining what topics are required in an information set, and how the topics fit together.

conbody.p:
Information architects need to:
Take a "big picture" view of the project content.
Develop samples and scenarios, and use them to derive information type hierarchies.
Follow the user assistance guidelines for defining hierarchies.
Describe the relationships among topics, and define the way information sets will combine and integrate.
Develop specialized maps for particular contexts, such as different output devices, different audiences, or different platforms.
Consider ways in which maps can get reused for different contexts and output formats.
Identify information gaps and missing topics for writers to create

Because information architects use maps, they don't need to worry about affecting topic content. They can define different sets of links and navigation for each context in which a topic is reused. Different information architects can define different maps across the same topics, without affecting each other. Each information architect can concentrate on maintaining the navigation and relationships that apply for their product or context, without worrying about other contexts. They can view and maintain all the relationships for a particular context in one place, instead of editing all the topics individually.
